description: From 23 April 2020, the Federal Ministry of Education, Science and Research in Austria applies special provisions to universities and teacher's colleges. Special provisions relate to: The division of the academic year; entry into force of curricula; admission periods; the notification of the continuation of studies; the taking of supplementary tests in art studies; the introductory and orientation phases of studies; the leave of absence; the deadline of study expirations at universities; courses and exams; the taking of exams by electronic means; the submission of bachelor, diploma and master theses, diploma and master theses in art studies and dissertations (also in art studies); periods of transition for studies and courses. Exams that have been taken or registered in the summer term 2020 and prior to the announcement of this policy are in accordance with these rules if without any grave flaws. The policy is slated to end on 30 September 2021. The counting of terms according to §§ 6 and 9 of this policy may also be valid following its termination if related to studies registered in the summer term 2020 and still eligible.
type_sub_cat: Higher education institutions (i.e. degree granting institutions)
institution_status: Higher education institutions allowed to open with conditions
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: From 23 April 2020, the Federal Ministry of Education, Science and Research in Austria applies special provisions to colleges and facilities for carrying out college study programmes. Special provisions relate to: The deadline of proofing mandatory additional tests; the holding of exams; the discontinuation of specific activities; the retry of an academic year; the submission of bachelor, diploma and master theses. Exams that have been taken or registered in the summer term 2020 and prior to the announcement of this policy are in accordance with these rules. The policy is slated to end on 30 September 2021.

description:
At Austrian press conference on August 17th, Education Minister Heinz Faßmann presented the plan for reopening schools. The minister “wants” schools and childcare facilities to resume regular instruction in the fall, but has outlined measures to reduce the spread of the virus.
Schools will be coordinated with the Health Ministry’s “Corona Ampel” (traffic light) that is planned to go live this fall. Some measures:
- Sick children should stay home.
- Windows in classrooms will be opened for at least five minutes every 20 minutes, even once temperatures grow colder during fall and winter.
- Masks must be worn upon entering and exiting school buildings, but are not required inside classrooms.
- Teachers will be provided with FFP2 masks and receive a flu shot.
type_sub_cat: Preschool or childcare facilities (generally for children ages 5 and below)
institution_status: Preschool or childcare facilities allowed to open with conditions
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: From March 13, 2020, in Austria, quarantine policies for residents of Paznautal and St. Anton am Arlberg (in the Tyrol county) are introduced for 14 days. Hence, nobody is permitted to enter or leave the areas while local residents are still permitted to leave their homes.

From March 13, 2020, in Austria, quarantine policies for residents of Paznautal and St. Anton am Arlberg (in the Tyrol county) are introduced for 14 days. Hence, nobody is permitted to enter or leave the areas while local residents are still permitted to leave their homes. UPDATE: On March 17th, the curfew was also announced for Sölden.
From March 19, 2020, in Tyrol, Austria, it is prohibited to leave the house. Exceptions are made for covering basic needs, providing services of general interest or getting to work.

From March 13, 2020, in Austria, quarantine policies for residents of Paznautal and St. Anton am Arlberg (in the Tyrol county) are introduced for 14 days. Hence, nobody is permitted to enter or leave the areas while local residents are still permitted to leave their homes. UPDATE: On March 26th, the policy was extended until April 13th 2020.

From April 13, 2020, Austria introduces a mandatory mask requirement obligating people to cover both their mouths and noses when in public. UPDATE: The original policy was strengthened by obligating people to wear masks when outside.

In Tyrol, the official measures forbiding to leave the house without important reason were set on March 16. This policy was valid until April 13th, 2020. UPDATE: In Tyrol, the official measures forbiding to leave the house without important reason were set on March 16. This policy was valid until April 13th, 2020.

From March 13, 2020, in Austria, quarantine policies for residents of Paznautal and St. Anton am Arlberg (in the Tyrol county) are introduced for 14 days. Hence, nobody is permitted to enter or leave the areas while local residents are still permitted to leave their homes. UPDATE: On April 10th, the policy was extended for St. Anton and Paznauntal until April 26th, and on April 12th, the policy was also extended for Sölden.

Being issolated since March 13, since April 23 those quarantine restrictions are lifted for the towns of Paznaun Ischgl, Galtür, Kappl and See as well as the municipality of St. Anton am Arlberg. UPDATE: Being issolated since March 13, since April 23 those quarantine restrictions are lifted for the towns of Paznaun Ischgl, Galtür, Kappl and See as well as the municipality of St. Anton am Arlberg.

The policy has no explicit end date.

description: From 7 March 2020, the Federal Ministry of Social Affairs, Health, Care and Consumer Protection in Austria announces that third-country nationals who in the last 14 days prior to departure have resided in a country for which there is a travel warning in connection with the occurrence of SARS-CoV-2 are, upon arrival in Austria, obliged to carry a health certificate which shows that molecular biological tests for SARS-CoV-2 were negative. Otherwise, entry can be restricted. The policy has no explicit end date.
target_geog_level: One or more regional groupings
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government,Police

description: From 9 March 2020, the Federal Ministry of Social Affairs, Health, Care and Consumer Protection in Austria prohibits passenger aircrafts departing from the People's Republic of China, Republic of Korea, Islamic Republic of Iran, and the Italian regions of Lombardy, Veneto, Emilia-Romagna, Marche, and Piedmont from landing in Austria for two weeks. Exceptions include cargo flights, mission flights, ambulance/rescue flights and transfer flights. The policy is slated to end on March 22.

description: From 11 March 2020, the Federal Ministry of Internal Affairs in Austria, in order to ensure "public tranquility, order and safety", temporarily reintroduces border controls by land on the internal borders with the Republic of Italy. Borders may only be crossed at certain border crossing points. The policy is slated to last for 10 days and therefore should end on March 20.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: From March 11 2020, the Federal Ministry of Social Affairs, Health, Care and Consumer Protection in Austria enacts that persons who want to enter Austria from Italy are obligated to carry a medical certificate in German, English or Italian which shows that molecular biological tests for SARS-CoV-2 were negative. The medical certificate cannot be older than four days upon entry. If failing to do so, persons can be denied entry. Exceptions exist (see compliance section). The policy is slated to end on April 3, at 12:00 o'clock.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government,Police

description: From March 11, 2020, Austria extended earlier restrictions prohibiting passenger aircrafts from the People's Republic of China, Republic of Korea, Islamic Republic of Iran, and the Italian regions of Lombardy, Veneto, Emilia-Romagna, Marche, Piedmont from landing to further include passenger aircrafts departing from entire Italy. UPDATE: Austria extended restrictions prohibiting passenger aircrafts from landing to also include passenger aircrafts departing from Italy.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Military,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government,Police

description: From March 11, 2020, Austria obligates persons who want to enter Austria from Italy to carry a medical certificate in German, English or Italian and show that the molecular biological test for SARS-CoV-2 is negative. The medical certificate cannot be older than four days upon entry. If failing to do so, persons can be denied entry. Austrian citizens or those with their main, secondary or habitual residence in Austria are allowed to enter but are obliged to commence immediately with a 14-day self-monitored home quarantine. Additionally, transit through Austria is permitted without a stopover, provided that the exit is ensured. Freight, commercial and commuter traffic is also exempted from this policy. The policy is in place until May 31, 2020. UPDATE: The original policy was to expire May 7, it has been extended to May 31.

Exceptions exist. The policy is slated to end on March 22. UPDATE: From 30 April 2020, the Republic of Korea is no longer affected by these restrictions. Exceptions are extended and now also include flights for transporting seasonal workers in the agricultural and silvicultural sectors as well as nursing and health personnel in compliance with § 1 of the "Verordnung über die Einreise auf dem Luftweg nach Österreich" (BGBl. II Nr. 105/2020, Version BGBl. II Nr. 196/2020). Landing restrictions are extended to May 22.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: From 14 April 2020, the Federal Ministry of Social Affairs, Health, Care and Consumer Protection in Austria enacts that persons who want to enter Austria from bordering countries are obligated to carry a medical certificate in German, English, Italian or French which shows that molecular biological tests for SARS-CoV-2 were negative. The medical certificate cannot be older than four days upon entry. If failing to do so, persons can be denied entry. Exceptions exist. The policy is slated to end on April 30. UPDATE: From 1 May 2020, the applicability of this policy to entries by land is made explicit. Exceptions for entering Austria are extended to those that are "necessarily to be enabled" to enter Austria if directly applicable to provisions of constitutional and Union law. Seasonal workers in the agricultural and silvicultural sectors as well as nursing and health personnel are allowed to enter Austria by rail or bus if there are no halts in between. An obligatory quarantine for 14 days also applies to these individuals. The municipalities of Vomp-Hinterriss, Mittelberg and Jungholz are now exempted. Those in need of serious medical assistance in Austria can, in addition to having an Austrian citizenship or being covered by a medical or private insurance in Austria, be exempted if they can submit a treatment assurance by an Austrian hospital related to exceptional medical reasons. The policy now also does not explicitly apply to public transport passengers if, in the case of travelling through foreign territory, there are no halts in between. Entry restrictions are extended to May 31.

description: From 14 April 2020, the Federal Ministry of Social Affairs, Health, Care and Consumer Protection in Austria enacts that persons who want to enter Austria from bordering countries are obligated to carry a medical certificate in German, English, Italian or French which shows that molecular biological tests for SARS-CoV-2 were negative. The medical certificate cannot be older than four days upon entry. If failing to do so, persons can be denied entry. Exceptions exist. The policy is slated to end on April 30. UPDATE: From 21 May, this policy now also applies to entries by water. Exceptions for public transport passengers now also explicitly apply to the respective drivers. Additionally, exceptions now also apply to individual travellers from Austria who have to travel through foreign territory in order to reach their target location in Austria. The guidelines that apply to medical certificates are changed.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Austrian Airlines will take to the air again on June 15. For the beginning, direct flights to ten destinations within or close to Europe will resume. All tickets can be rebooked flexibly and higher hygiene standards (e.g. mandatory masks for travelers, higher frequency of disinfection etc.) apply throughout the check-in process and flight. The following destinations can be reached from Vienna in the first week of the restart (June 15-21):
Amsterdam, Athens, Basel, Berlin, Brussels, Bucharest, Dubrovnik, Düsseldorf, Frankfurt, Geneva, Hamburg, Copenhagen, Larnaka, London, Munich, Paris, Prishtina, Sarajevo, Skopje, Sofia, Stockholm, Stuttgart, Tel Aviv, Thessaloniki, Tirana, Varna und Zurich.

In the second week (June 22-28), Belgrade, Graz, Innsbruck, Kiyv, Kosice, Milan, Nice, Prague, Split und Warsaw are to follow.
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
From June 16, Austria permits again travels to and from 31 European countries. Travelers do not need to go into quarantine or present a coronavirus test result when traveling to Austria from these countries. Different rules may still apply for entering some of these countries coming from Austria. The 31 countries are:

Belgium, Bulgaria, Denmark and the Färöer islands, Germany, Estonia, Finland, France, Greece, Iceland, Ireland, Italy (a travel warning is still in force for the province of Lombardy), Croatia, Latvia, Liechtenstein, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Malta, the Netherlands, Norway, Poland, Romania, Switzerland, Cyprus and the micro states Andorra, Monaco, San Marino and the Vatican City.

description: In Austria, Anyone entering the country from one of 32 states or territories defined as having an unstable or risky COVID-19 situation has to self-quarantine at home for 14 days. If the result is negative, there is no need for home quarantine. Alternatively, travelers can also present a negative test result not older than four days upon crossing the border. The countries and territories classified as risky are: Albania, Bangladesh, Belarus, Bosnia-Herzegovina, Brazil, Bulgaria, Chile, Egypt, Ecuador, India, Indonesia, Iran, Kosovo, Mexico, Moldova, Montenegro, Nigeria, Northern Macedonia, Pakistan, Peru, Philippines, Portugal, Romania, Russian Federation, Sweden, Senegal, Serbia, South Africa, Turkey, Ukraine, United States and Hubei Province (China).
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Ministry/Department of Foreign Affairs

description: From 21 June 2020, the Federal Ministry of Social Affairs, Health, Care and Consumer Protection in Austria enacts that the People's Republic of China, the Islamic Republic of Iran, the Lombardy, Portugal, the United Kingdom, Sweden, the Russian Federation, Ukraine and Belarus are banned from landing aircrafts in Austria. Exceptions are extended when compared to the regulatory situation of June 15. The policy is slated to end on June 30. UPDATE: From 16 July, the Arab Republic of Egypt, the Republics of Serbia, Kosovo, North Macedonia, Albania, Bulgaria and Moldova, Montenegro, Bosnia and Herzegovina and Romania are added to, and the Lombardy removed from, the list of countries banned from landing aircrafts in Austria. Landing bans are extended to July 31.

description:
Health Minister Rudolf Anschober (Greens) announced that starting this Thursday, July 16, planes coming from 10 countries will no longer be permitted to land in Austria due to rising coronavirus infection rates there. Including these new restrictions, Austria bans direct flight traffic with 18 countries in total. These countries are:
Belarus; China; United Kingdom; Iran; Portugal; Russia; Sweden; Ukraine; Bulgaria; Romania; Moldava; Egypt; Serbia; Bosnia & Herzegovina; North Macedonia; Albania; Kosovo; Montenegro UPDATE: The policy ended on July 31st 2020.
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings

description:
The Austrian government issued a travel warning for the Spanish mainland, which will enter into force on Monday, August 10.
The warning is currently not valid for the Spanish islands, i.e. the Balearic islands and the Canaries.That means that travelers coming back from the Spanish mainland to Austria will have to show a negative COVID-19 test result, otherwise they need to enter a 10-day quarantine.

description: From 16 June 2020, the Federal Ministry of Internal Affairs in Austria, in order to ensure "public tranquility, order and safety", temporarily reintroduces border controls by land on the internal borders with the Republic of Slovenia and Hungary. Borders may only be crossed at certain border crossing points. The policy is slated to end on November 11. UPDATE: From 12 November 2020, border controls are extended to 11 May 2021.

description:
From June 16, Austria permits again travels to and from 31 European countries. Travelers do not need to go into quarantine or present a coronavirus test result when traveling to Austria from these countries. Different rules may still apply for entering some of these countries coming from Austria. The 31 countries are:

Belgium, Bulgaria, Denmark and the Färöer islands, Germany, Estonia, Finland, France, Greece, Iceland, Ireland, Italy (a travel warning is still in force for the province of Lombardy), Croatia, Latvia, Liechtenstein, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Malta, the Netherlands, Norway, Poland, Romania, Switzerland, Cyprus and the micro states Andorra, Monaco, San Marino and the Vatican City. UPDATE: Due to rising numbers in the country, a new policies on traveling to Austria applies from December 19th. Almost all countries are announced as high risk area and are not allowed to enter Austria without restrictions anymore.
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Ministry/Department of Foreign Affairs

description:
The Austrian government announced that from January 15th 2021, people entering Austria from a defined high-risk area are obligated to submit key information, in order to facilitate contact tracing. The pre-travel clearance online form serves this purpose and needs to be submitted electronically before entering the country. In exceptional cases, e.g. if someone does not have the technical means to fill out the document online, the form can also be filled out and used in printed form. 
Some exceptions exist for certain groups (e.g. regular commuters).
type_sub_cat: Travel History Form (e.g. documents where traveler has recently been)

description: From February 28 2020, the Federal Ministry of Social Affairs, Health, Care and Consumer Protection in Austria enacts that air carriers are required [...] to immediately report passengers who have been in an area for which a travel warning related to the occurrence of SARS-CoV-2 has been pronounced in the last 14 days before the start of the trip, and who have arrived at an airport in Austria. If passengers from countries for which a travel warning related to SARS-CoV-2 has been issued are confirmed to be infected with SARS-CoV-2, air carriers are required to immediately provide the entire passenger list. The policy is slated to end on June 30.

description:
From September 15th, Vienna residents can register for a free flu shot provided by the city’s health authorities.
Either by clicking on “Impftermin buchen” on impfservice.wien (if you don’t yet have an account, creating one is mandatory) or by calling the hotline 01/4000-8015.

description: Starting this October, the City of Vienna will offer free flu shots. The city government has prepared 400,000 shots with which it wants to triple flu vaccination coverage rates from 8% in previous years to 24%. The shots will be administered in the Wiener Messe.

description:
In Austria from August 19, Defense Minister Klaudia Tanner announced that she will send 800 additional soldiers to Austrian borders to support health officials in conducting health check-ups.
Additionally, Chancellor Sebastian Kurz is ordering 500 police officers to the borders. UPDATE: UPDATE: To support health officials in conducting health checks at the borders, the government will send 60 additional soldiers to the Styrian-Slovenian border and 60 more to the border crossings located in Carinthia.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Ministry/Department of Foreign Affairs,Military,Police

description:
The Austrian government has established a “strategic reserve” of masks and protective gear as a reaction to the scramble for equipment at the beginning of the pandemic.
In cooperation with the Red Cross, the government purchased 2.6 million respiratory masks, 44.4 million surgical masks, 1.7 million examination gloves, 430,000 protective overalls, 37,000 protective goggles, 150,000 disposable aprons and 19,500 pulse oximeters with finger clips.
In addition, 9,000 oxygen masks, 50,000 CoV test kits and 991,000 CoV rapid tests were stored in five facilities of the Austrian Bundesheer (Federal Army).
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Ministry/Department of Foreign Affairs

description: From March 16, 2020, Austria declares that citizens must suspend all non-essential activities outside their homes; exemptions are essential work, for essential shopping or services, helping those in need of support, physical activity if alone or with co-living persons. UPDATE: The Lockdown in Austria that started on March 16th, 2020, ended on May 1st, 2020.

From April 14, 2020, Austria introduces a mandatory mask requirement obligating people to cover both their mouths and noses when entering small stores (maximum size of 400 square meters) that have just opened again.
From May 1st, 2020, Austria is enforcing a new hygiene rule, where people, who enter any confined public space, have to wear a mask or something that covers their mouth and nose.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: As restaurants open up on May 15th, 2020, the Austrian government requires the staff to wear masks. Furthermore, the customers have to wear masks when entering the restaurant until they seated at a table.

As restaurants open up on May 15th, 2020, the Austrian government requires the staff to wear masks. Furthermore, the customers have to wear masks when entering the restaurant until they seated at a table. From June 15th, 2020, Customers are no longer required to wear masks when entering the restaurant. UPDATE: From June 15th, 2020, the Austrian government no longer requires customers to wear masks when entering a restaurant. The staff, who is still in contact with the guests, is still required to wear a mask or something that covers their nose and mouth.
While from June 15th, 2020, masks are no longer required for car pooling, the Austrian government still requires people to wear masks when using public transportation.
From June 15th, 2020, the Austrian government requires customers and staff in pharmacies to continue to wear masks, while in other stores it is no longer necessary for customers.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Starting June 15th, 2020, the Austrian government requires staff in restaurants, who cannot keep a distance of 1 meter from the customer, to continue to wear masks or something to fully cover nose and mouth.

description: From June 15th, 2020, the Austrian government requires employees in service-jobs, who cannot keep a distance of 1 meter from the customer (such as hairdresser), to wear a mask.

description: From 16 March 2020, the Federal Ministry of Social Affairs, Health, Care and Consumer Protection in Austria enacts that entering public spaces is prohibited. Exceptions exist. The policy is slated to end on March 22. UPDATE: From 20 March 2020, if protection measures for lowering the risk of infection are implemented, they may replace minimum distance provisions. Funerals within closest family circles are now exempted from lockdown restrictions. Exceptions for entering work places are now valid only if professional activities cannot be carried out outside of the work place. However, it is made explicit that professional activities are preferably to be carried out outside of the work place if possible and mutually agreed upon by employees and employers. Lockdown restrictions are extended to April 13.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: From 16 March 2020, the Federal Ministry of Social Affairs, Health, Care and Consumer Protection in Austria enacts that entering public spaces is prohibited. Exceptions exist. The policy is slated to end on March 22. UPDATE: From 14 April 2020, exceptions are extended and now include weddings and funerals within close family circles. The purchase of goods and services exempted from lockdown restrictions now corresponds to the provisions as per BGBl. II Nr. 96/2020 idgF. Face and nose covering in areas where usually not required through "mechanical safeguards" [probably a face mask; W.H.] must be mutually agreed upon by employees and employers. Lockdown restrictions are extended to April 30.

description: From 17 November 2020, the Federal Ministry of Social Affairs, Health, Care and Consumer Protection in Austria enacts that leaving or staying outside one's private living area (which also includes living units within accommodation providers or in retirement and nursing homes as well as homes for those with disabilities) is prohibited. Exceptions exist. The policy is slated to end on November 26. UPDATE: From 27 November 2020, exceptions are slightly specified. In addition to utilizing health services, getting tested for COVID-19 in the context of screening programmes may also be exempted from lockdown restrictions. It is now made explicit that staying outside for recovering purposes is only allowed if alone, with those from the same household or those according to § 1, section 1, no. 3, lit. a) of the source document, that is, here, exceptions are extended. When allowedly contacting other persons, it is now to be ensured that, on the one end, persons from one outside household at most and, on the other hand, only one person, are involved hereby at the same time. Lockdown restrictions are extended to December 6.

description:
On March 15, 2020, the Austrian government adopted the COVID-19 Act and several regulations that tighten restrictions already put in place to prevent or contain the spread of the novel coronavirus in Austria and to make money available to deal with the economic fallout from the pandemic. The measures include the following:

-The establishment of a crisis management fund
-Measures to support employers and employees affected by COVID-19
-Closures of or restrictions on entering certain business premises
-The reintroduction of border controls and travel restrictions from certain countries to Austria
-Prohibition on gathering in public places

description: In Austria, Anyone entering the country from one of 32 states or territories defined as having an unstable or risky COVID-19 situation has to self-quarantine at home for 14 days. If the result is negative, there is no need for home quarantine. Alternatively, travelers can also present a negative test result not older than four days upon crossing the border. The countries and territories classified as risky are: Albania, Bangladesh, Belarus, Bosnia-Herzegovina, Brazil, Bulgaria, Chile, Egypt, Ecuador, India, Indonesia, Iran, Kosovo, Mexico, Moldova, Montenegro, Nigeria, Northern Macedonia, Pakistan, Peru, Philippines, Portugal, Romania, Russian Federation, Sweden, Senegal, Serbia, South Africa, Turkey, Ukraine, United States and Hubei Province (China). UPDATE: From August 17, Austria issued a travel warning for Croatia due to rising coronavirus numbers in the Adriatic country and urged all travelers to return to Austria as soon as possible. Anyone returning from Croatia on Monday or later has to present a negative COVID-19 test result or enter a 10-days quarantine.
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Ministry/Department of Foreign Affairs

description:
The Austrian Foreign Ministry issued a travel warning for the countries of the Western Balkans due to rising coronavirus cases in the region.
Concretely, the ministry advises not to travel to Serbia, Montenegro, Bosnia & Herzegovina, North Macedonia, Albania and Kosovo.
Travelers coming from these countries to Austria need to self-quarantine for 14 days or show a negative COVID-19 test result.

description:
The federal states of Lower Austria and Upper Austria shortened the quarantine period for COVID-19 suspected cases to 10 days from previously 14 days.
The change follows a recommendation from the Ministry of Health.
The quarantine can only be ended if there are still no symptoms after 10 days; for people who tested positive for the coronavirus in the past or who show symptoms, a negative test result is obligatory.

description:
Individuals coming from the countries below are required to present a negative  PCR test on arrival (within 48 hours) or go into ten day mandatory quarantine.

The following are considered high-risk areas by the Austrian government: Andorra, Albania, Argentina, Bahrain, Bangladesh, Belarus, the areas of Brussels and Wallonia in Belgium, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Brazil, Bulgaria (the regions Blagoevgrad, Burgas, Dobrich, Gabrovo, Jambol, Kardzhali, Montana, Plovdiv, Rasgrad, Shumen, Sliven, Smoljan, Sofia, Stara Zagora, Targovishte, Varna only), Chile, Costa Rica, Croatia (except Brod-Posavina, Istria, Koprivnica-Križevci, Osijek-Baranja, Šibenik-Knin, Varaždin, and Zadar), Czech Republic, Ecuador, Egypt, Île-de-France (Paris) and Provence-Alpes-Cote d’Azur in France, India, Indonesia, Iran, Israel, Kosovo, Kuwait, Maldives, Mexico, Moldavia, Montenegro, Nigeria, North Macedonia, Pakistan, Peoples Republic of China – Province Hubei, Peru, Philippines, Lisbon and Norte in Portugal, Romania, Russian Federation, Senegal, Serbia, South Africa, mainland Spain and the Balearic Islands, Turkey, the areas of the North East, the East Midlands, Yorkshire and the Humber in the United Kingdom, Ukraine and USA.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Fines,Mandatory (Unspecified/Implied)
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Ministry/Department of Foreign Affairs,Military,Police

description:
From 19th of December, the Federal Ministry of Social Affairs, Health, Care and Consumer Protection in Austria enacts that persons entering the country from a defined risk area are required to quarantine for 10 days upon arrival. After 5 days of quarantine at the earliest, you may take a PCR or antigen COVID test to shorten the quarantine. Moreover, it is possible to end the quarantine if the person decides to leave the country.

The only countries considered as non-risk areas are Australia, Finland, Ireland, Iceland, Japan, New Zealand, Norway, South Korea, Uruguay, and the Vatican, which are exempted from the policy.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
From 19th of December, the Federal Ministry of Social Affairs, Health, Care and Consumer Protection in Austria enacts that persons entering the country from a defined risk area are required to quarantine for 10 days upon arrival. After 5 days of quarantine at the earliest, you may take a PCR or antigen COVID test to shorten the quarantine. Moreover, it is possible to end the quarantine if the person decides to leave the country.

Only countries considered as non-risk areas are exempted from the policy. UPDATE: The policy was extended until March 31st 2021.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
From March 17, 2020, Austria announced the closing of restaurants and bars.

From April 21, 2020, Austria announced that:
From May 1: all shops and stores can reopen, including hair & beauty salons;
From May 15: restaurants, bars and other businesses in the hospitality industry can reopen (until 23:00 in the night), for staff it’s mandatory to wear mask
 UPDATE: The original policy had restaurant and bars close from 3PM on; later - policy closed restaurants and bars entirely. 

The new policy indicates that from:
May 1: all shops and stores can reopen, including hair & beauty salons;
May 15: restaurants, bars and other businesses in the hospitality industry can reopen (until 23:00 in the night), for staff it’s mandatory to wear mask
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government,Police

description: From 16 March 2020, the Federal Ministry for Social Affairs, Health, Care and Consumer Protection in Austria enacts that entering the costumer areas of trading, service, leisure and sports facilities for the purpose of purchasing goods or making use of services as well as leisure and sports facilities is prohibited. Exceptions exist. The policy is slated to end on March 22. UPDATE: From 20 March 2020, post service providers according to § 2, number 14 of the source document are also exempted from restrictions, however, only for providing postal services, activities exempted elsewhere or telecommunication. Restrictions for trading, service, leisure and sports facilities are extended to April 13.

description: From 16 March 2020, the Federal Ministry for Social Affairs, Health, Care and Consumer Protection in Austria enacts that entering the costumer areas of trading, service, leisure and sports facilities for the purpose of purchasing goods or making use of services as well as leisure and sports facilities is prohibited. Exceptions exist. The policy is slated to end on March 22. UPDATE: From 20 March 2020, post service providers according to § 2, number 14 of the source document are also exempted from restrictions, however, only for providing postal services, activities exempted elsewhere or telecommunication. Restrictions for trading, service, leisure and sports facilities are extended to April 13.

description: From 16 March 2020, the Federal Ministry for Social Affairs, Health, Care and Consumer Protection in Austria enacts that entering the costumer areas of trading, service, leisure and sports facilities for the purpose of purchasing goods or making use of services as well as leisure and sports facilities is prohibited. Exceptions exist. The policy is slated to end on March 22. UPDATE: From 23 March 2020, exceptions for drug stores and markets, the selling of medical products, sanitary articles, therapeutic and medical aids, the selling of fodder, the selling and maintaining of safety and emergency products as well as agriculture trade are valid from 7:40 am to 7 pm at the longest on workdays. Exceptions for food trade and agricultural direct marketers (outside of selling points of food producers) are valid from 7:40 am to 7 pm at the longest on workdays.

description:
From March 16, 2020, Austria closes non-essential businesses with the exception of grocery stores, pharmacies, drug stores, post offices, banks, and other essential businesses.
From April 14th, hardware stores, garden centers and shops smaller than 400 square meters may reopen in Austria, albeit with restrictions how many people may enter at any one time. UPDATE: In Austria, from March 16th many non-essencial businesses and governmental services were closed. From:
May 1: all shops and stores can reopen, including hair & beauty salons
 May 15: restaurants, bars and other businesses in the hospitality industry can reopen (until 23:00 in the night), for staff it’s mandatory to wear mask

description: From 16 March 2020, the Federal Ministry for Social Affairs, Health, Care and Consumer Protection in Austria enacts that entering the costumer areas of trading, service, leisure and sports facilities for the purpose of purchasing goods or making use of services as well as leisure and sports facilities is prohibited. Exceptions exist. The policy is slated to end on March 22. UPDATE: From 14 April 2020, exceptions are extended and now also include filling stations and affiliated car washes, car and bicycle service stations, building material, iron, timber and precious metals trades as well as building and garten centres and pawn offices. Exceptions for building material, iron, timber and precious metals trades as well as building and garten centres, and pawn offices are valid from 07:40 am to 7 pm at the longest on workdays. Additionally, if inside costumer areas have a size of less than 400 m², other trade facilities (according to § 2, section 4 of the source document) may be exempted as well (in line with the provisions stated in § 2, section 4 of the source document). Operators of these other trade facilities are required to ensure that the number of costumers in costumer areas is regulated such that for 20 m² of selling space only 1 customer may be allowed to be located there, for selling spaces of less than 20 m² no more than 1 costumer is allowed to be located there. Exceptions may now only be granted if employees in situations of costumer contact and costumers from 6 (years of age) upwards wear a face mask (does not apply to health and care services where alternative provisions and recommendations are in place separately) and minimum distance (1m) measures are followed (does not apply to health and care services). Restrictions for trading, service, leisure and sports facilities are extended to April 30.
institution_status: This type of business  ("Retail Businesses") is closed/locked down
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: From 17 March 2020, the Federal Ministry for Social Affairs, Health, Care and Consumer Protection in Austria enacts that entering the premises of all modes of operation in the catering industry is prohibited. Exceptions exist. The policy is slated to end on March 22. UPDATE: From 1 May 2020, it is explicitly stated that minimum distance measures are to be followed towards those not from the same household if exceptions are granted. For takeouts of pre-ordered meals, face covering is required additionally. Exceptions may now also be granted to instances of occupational necessity. Catering industry restrictions are extended to June 30.
institution_status: This type of business  ("Restaurants") is closed/locked down
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: From 16 March 2020, the Federal Ministry for Social Affairs, Health, Care and Consumer Protection in Austria enacts that entering the costumer areas of trading, service, leisure and sports facilities for the purpose of purchasing goods or making use of services as well as leisure and sports facilities is prohibited. Exceptions exist. The policy is slated to end on March 22. UPDATE: From 1 May 2020, restrictions for trading and service facilities are lifted. Entering the costumer areas of business premises of any sort is now allowed if the conditions according to § 2, sections 1 to 5 of the source document are met. Entering sports ground for carrying out sports activities and leisure facilities (with the exception of within private living space and according to § 9, section 2 of the source document) for visitors remains to be prohibited.
institution_status: This type of business  ("Retail Businesses") is closed/locked down
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: From 17 March 2020, the Federal Ministry for Social Affairs, Health, Care and Consumer Protection in Austria enacts that entering the premises of all modes of operation in the catering industry is prohibited. Exceptions exist. The policy is slated to end on March 22. UPDATE: From 15 May 2020, catering industry restrictions are lifted. Entering the premises of all modes of operation in the catering industry is now allowed if the provisions stated in § 6, sections 2 to 10 of the source document are followed. This also applies to gastronomical facilities for the provision of meals and drinks within accommodation providers. Chosen facilities are exempted from the obligation to follow these rules.

description: From 1 May 2020, entering the costumer areas of business premises of any sort (or outdoor markets) is allowed if social distancing, face covering or other infection protection measures are followed (see [type_business_var]). Entering sports grounds for carrying out sports activities is, with exceptions, prohibited. Entering leisure facilities for entertaining, amusing or recreational purposes is, with exceptions, prohibited for visitors. The policy is slated to end on June 30. UPDATE: From 15 May 2020, entering sports grounds is now generally prohibited. Exceptions are revised accordingly. Entering the visitor areas of animal parks and zoos is now allowed if conditions according to § 2, section 1, numbers 1 to 5 (§ 1, section 1 for outdoor visitor areas) of the source document are met. In the context of leisure facility restrictions, entering the premises of cruise vessels is now prohibited for those of occasional character ("im Gelegenheitsverkehr"). For dance schools, dancing couples may be exempted if from the same household and each couple is provided a dance floor of 10 m² at the least, private lessons are generally allowed. Drive-in cinemas (for multi-lane motor vehicles) may now also be exempted from restrictions.
institution_status: This type of business  ("Retail Businesses") is allowed to open with conditions
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Fines,Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

UPDATE: From 15 May 2020, entering sports grounds is now generally prohibited. Exceptions are revised accordingly. Entering the visitor areas of animal parks and zoos is now allowed if conditions according to § 2, section 1, numbers 1 to 5 (§ 1, section 1 for outdoor visitor areas) of the source document are met. In the context of leisure facility restrictions, entering the premises of cruise vessels is now prohibited for those of occasional character ("im Gelegenheitsverkehr"). For dance schools, dancing couples may be exempted if from the same household and each couple is provided a dance floor of 10 m² at the least, private lessons are generally allowed. Drive-in cinemas (for multi-lane motor vehicles) may now also be exempted from restrictions.
institution_status: This type of business  ("Information service activities") is allowed to open with conditions
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
From May 29th, hotels and other accomodation facilities can reopen in Austria. Nevertheless, certain control measures have to be insured: 
- Ensure a minimum distance of 1 meter (Place information by means of displays, signs, stands, floor markings or other aids in the entrance areas and at the reception of the accommodation company and etc).
- Design the catering area (Observe guidelines for catering establishments for general information)
- Adapt additional offers (fitness areas and wellness areas, according to their requirements)
- Place recommendations for behavior that are clearly visible to the guest
institution_status: This type of business  ("Other Businesses") is allowed to open with conditions
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: From 15 May 2020, the Federal Ministry for Social Affairs, Health, Care and Consumer Protection in Austria enacts that entering the premises of all modes of operation in the catering industry is allowed if certain conditions are met (see [type_business_var]). For some facilities, following these rules is not explicitly mandatory (see exceptions section). The policy is slated to end on June 30. UPDATE: From 29 May 2020, the joint admission of multiple interrelated visitor groups may be allowed if minimum distance measures are followed or appropriate safeguards for social distancing are installed. Operators and employees may forego wearing a face mask in situations of customer contact if appropriate safeguards for social distancing are available. Catering industry provisions are extended to August 31.

description: In Austria, the original policy limited the working time and number of people of restaurants and bars, as well as mandatory masks wearing requirements for customers and personnel existed (from May 15th). Starting on June 15th, people will be able to sit on a restaurant table with more than 4 people (also from different households), masks will be mandatory only for personnel and restaurants and bars can stay opened until 1:00 am in the morning (before until 23:00).
institution_status: This type of business  ("Restaurants") is allowed to open with conditions
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: From 15 June 2020, the Federal Ministry for Social Affairs, Health, Care and Consumer Protection in Austria enacts that entering the premises of all modes of operation in the catering industry is allowed if certain conditions are met (see [type_business_var]). The policy is slated to end on August 31.

description: From 29 May 2020, the Federal Ministry for Social Affairs, Health, Care and Consumer Protection in Austria enacts that entering the premises of all modes of operation in the catering industry is allowed if certain conditions are met (see [type_business_var]). Conditions have changed when compared to the regulatory situation of May 15. For some facilities, following these rules is not explicitly mandatory (see exceptions section). The policy is slated to end on August 31. UPDATE: From 15 June 2020, opening hours for the admission of customers are extended and now go from 6 am to 1 am the next day. The admission of visitor groups is no longer attached to conditions. Wearing a face mask in confined spaces is no longer mandatory. The takeaway of meals and drinks is no longer attached to conditions.
institution_status: This type of business  ("Restaurants") is allowed to open with conditions
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: From 30 May 2020, entering the costumer areas of business premises of any sort (or outdoor markets) is allowed if social distancing, face covering or other infection protection measures are followed (see [type_business_var]). Entering sports grounds is allowed if conditions according to § 2, section 1, numbers 1 to 3 and § 8, sections 2 to 5 (§ 1, section 1 and § 8, sections 2 to 5 for outdoor sports grounds) of the source document are met. Entering the visitor areas of leisure facilities is now allowed if the conditions according to § 2, section 1, numbers 1 to 3 (§ 1, section 1 for outdoor visitor areas) of the source document are met. Entering the premises of the sex trade industry remains to be prohibited. The policy is slated to end on June 30. UPDATE: From 15 June 2020, when entering the costumer areas of business premises of any sort (or outdoor markets), now only social distancing measures are to be followed (also applies to sports grounds and leisure facilities). Face covering is still mandatory for costumers when entering pharmacies and for their operators and employees whenever there is costumer contact (here, provisions with respect to costumers for being exempted from face covering measures are no longer valid). When carrying out sports activities at sports grounds, keeping a minimum distance of 2 metres now generally applies. Provisions for outdoor visitor areas of leisure facilities are no longer valid.
institution_status: This type of business  ("Retail Businesses") is allowed to open with conditions
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

Face covering is still mandatory for costumers when entering pharmacies and for their operators and employees whenever there is costumer contact (here, provisions with respect to costumers for being exempted from face covering measures are no longer valid). When carrying out sports activities at sports grounds, keeping a minimum distance of 2 metres now generally applies. Provisions for outdoor visitor areas of leisure facilities are no longer valid.
institution_status: This type of business  ("Other Businesses") is allowed to open with conditions
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: From 15 June 2020, the Federal Ministry for Social Affairs, Health, Care and Consumer Protection in Austria enacts that entering the premises of all modes of operation in the catering industry is allowed if certain conditions are met (see [type_business_var]). Conditions have changed when compared to the regulatory situation of May 29. For some facilities, following these rules is not explicitly mandatory (see exceptions section). The policy is slated to end on August 31. UPDATE: From 1 July 2020, opening hours for the admission of customers are extended and now go from 5 am to 1 am the next day. The allocation of seats is no longer required to be carried out by operators or employees. The obligation to wear a face mask for operators and employees (or having appropriate safeguards for social distancing alternatively) whenever there is customer contact is no longer valid. Self-service may now be allowed if hygienic precautions are in place. Catering industry provisions are extended to December 31.
institution_status: This type of business  ("Restaurants") is allowed to open with conditions
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: From 15 June 2020, entering the costumer areas of business premises of any sort (or outdoor markets), sports grounds and the visitor areas of leisure facilities is allowed if social distancing measures are followed (except for pharmacies where face covering measures are to be followed additionally). Furthermore, entering sports grounds is attached to conditions according to § 8, sections 2 to 5 (§ 1, section 1 and § 8, sections 2 to 5 for outdoor sports grounds) of the source document. Entering the premises of the sex trade industry remains to be prohibited. The policy is slated to end on June 30. UPDATE: From 1 July 2020, provisions for pharmacies now only apply to those that are public. Here, face covering may now be foregone if appropriate safeguards are available alternatively. Provisions for outdoor sports grounds are no longer valid. In the context of sports grounds, carrying out sports activities is (in the case of sports where physical contact is common, in the context of clubs ("Vereinen") or on non-public sports grounds) now only attached to the condition of working out and implementing a COVID-19 prevention concept where provisions are narrowed and reformulated (as per § 8, section 2 of the source document) when compared to the regulatory situation before. Provisions for the carrying out of sports activities through top athletes no longer explicitly refer to instances of falling below social distancing provisions. The carrying out of sports activities at airfields is no longer explicitly attached to social distancing conditions. The prohibition of entering the premises of sex trade facilities expired on June 30. Provisions for business premises, sports grounds and leisure facilities are extended to December 31.
institution_status: This type of business  ("Retail Businesses") is allowed to open with conditions
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Fines,Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description:
The Austrian ski school union has released new corona guidelines for the upcoming winter season.
-Ski and snowboard instructors must be tested for the coronavirus on a regular basis. The union has requested for testing costs to be paid for by the Ministry of Agriculture, Regions, and Tourism.
-Groups are capped at ten individuals, including the instructor.
-All students must register their contact information.
-In case an individual shows corona symptoms, he or she must be separated from the group.
-Masks are required whenever the minimum distance cannot be kept.
institution_status: This type of business  ("Other Businesses") is allowed to open with conditions
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: From 1 July 2020, the Federal Ministry for Social Affairs, Health, Care and Consumer Protection in Austria enacts that entering the premises of all modes of operation in the catering industry is allowed if certain conditions are met (see [type_business_var]). Conditions have changed when compared to the regulatory situation of June 15. For some facilities, following these rules is not explicitly mandatory (see exceptions section). The policy is slated to end on December 31. UPDATE: From 14 September 2020, the consumption of meals and drinks in confined spaces is only allowed when sitting at prescribed places of serving. The obligation to wear a face mask for operators and employees (or having appropriate safeguards for social distancing alternatively) whenever there is costumer contact is reintroduced for confined spaces.

description: From 14 September 2020, the Federal Ministry for Social Affairs, Health, Care and Consumer Protection in Austria enacts that entering the premises of all modes of operation in the catering industry is allowed if certain conditions are met (see [type_business_var]). Conditions have changed when compared to the regulatory situation of July 1. For some facilities, following these rules is not explicitly mandatory (see exceptions section). The policy is slated to end on December 31. UPDATE: From 21 September 2020, the admission of visitor groups is again attached to conditions. They may be admitted if consisting of 10 adults at the maximum in addition to their underage children or minors for whom they have the responsibility, or from the same household. The obligation to wear a face mask now also applies to costumers in confined spaces whenever not at their seat.
institution_status: This type of business  ("Restaurants") is allowed to open with conditions
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: From 14 September 2020, entering the costumer areas of business premises of any sort (or outdoor markets), sports grounds and the visitor areas of leisure facilities is allowed if certain conditions are met (see [type_business_var]). For business premises, sports grounds and leisure facilities, conditions have changed when compared to the regulatory situation of July 24. The policy is slated to end on December 31. UPDATE: From 21 September 2020, the obligation to wear a face mask when entering costumer areas in confined spaces now also includes "connective structures of business premises which are structurally connected" (such as shopping centres) and outdoor markets. Provisions for the carrying out of sports activities through top athletes are slightly relaxed when compared to the regulatory situation before.
institution_status: This type of business  ("Retail Businesses") is allowed to open with conditions
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: From 21 September 2020, the Federal Ministry for Social Affairs, Health, Care and Consumer Protection in Austria enacts that entering the premises of all modes of operation in the catering industry is allowed if certain conditions are met (see [type_business_var]). Conditions have changed when compared to the regulatory situation of September 14. For some facilities, following these rules is not explicitly mandatory (see exceptions section). The policy is slated to end on December 31. UPDATE: From 25 September 2020, conditions with respect to the admission of visitor groups now only apply to confined spaces. For the states of Salzburg, Tirol and Vorarlberg, opening hours for the admission of costumers are limited to between 5 am and 10 pm at the longest (this provision is due to end 3 days after the commencement of the next set of related COVID-19 measures).
institution_status: This type of business  ("Restaurants") is allowed to open with conditions
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: From 25 September 2020, the Federal Ministry for Social Affairs, Health, Care and Consumer Protection in Austria enacts that entering the premises of all modes of operation in the catering industry is allowed if certain conditions are met (see [type_business_var]). Conditions have changed when compared to the regulatory situation of September 21. For some facilities, following these rules is not explicitly mandatory (see exceptions section). The policy is slated to end on December 31. UPDATE: From 25 October 2020, the admission of visitor groups may now only be allowed if consisting of 6 persons at the maximum (in addition to up to 6 underage children of theirs or minors for whom they have the responsibility) or exclusively from the same household. The admission of visitor groups outdoors is now attached to conditions. They may be admitted if consisting of 12 persons at the maximum (in addition to up to 6 underage children of theirs or minors for whom they have the responsibility) or exclusively from the same household (both these changes are slated to end on November 22). The consumption of alcoholic drinks after closing time is now prohibited within 50 metres of catering industry facilities. The consumption of meals and drinks when not sitting at prescribed places of serving is now generally prohibited except at outdoor food stalls. Face covering is now generally mandatory for operators/employees whenever there is costumer contact and appropriate safeguards for social distancing are not available and costumers whenever not at their seat. Exceptions are extended and now also include homes for those with disabilities. The facilities exempted from catering industry provisions (outside of mass transportation facilities) are now only discharged from opening hour and closing time provisions (§§ 2 and 2a of the source document). Mass transportation facilities are now separately listed and exempted from catering industry provisions according to § 6, sections 2, 2a, 3a and 4 of the source document.
institution_status: This type of business  ("Restaurants") is allowed to open with conditions
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Fines,Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: From 21 September 2020, entering the costumer areas of business premises of any sort (or outdoor markets), sports grounds and the visitor areas of leisure facilities is allowed if certain conditions are met (see [type_business_var]). For business premises and sports grounds, conditions have changed when compared to the regulatory situation of September 14. The policy is slated to end on December 31. UPDATE: From 25 October 2020, face covering measures now explicitly do not apply to "wet rooms" in the context of sports grounds. Exceptions to social distancing measures now only apply to sports activities where physical contact is common, to instances in the context of sports activities where shortly falling below minimum distance provisions is typical of the respective sport or to instances of necessary mutual and safety assistance. Additionally, face covering measures now explicitly do not apply to sports activities.

description: From 3 November 2020, entering the costumer areas of business premises of any sort (or outdoor markets) is allowed if social distancing, face covering or other infection protection measures are followed (see [type_business_var]). Entering sports grounds for carrying out sports activities is, with exceptions (which are almost the same as has been enacted on May 1, yet, slightly narrowed and relaxed and with the addition of COVID-19 prevention concept provisions), prohibited. Entering leisure facilities for entertaining, amusing or recreational purposes is, with exceptions (which are almost the same as has been enacted on May 1, yet, slightly narrowed and relaxed in general), prohibited. The policy is slated to end on November 30 and replaced by the previous set of policies on December 1.
institution_status: This type of business  ("Retail Businesses") is allowed to open with conditions
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Fines,Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description:
In Austria from November 3, All ski resorts are closed to the general public during lockdown. Ski area openings scheduled for November have been postponed to December. Professional ski teams will still be able to train.
Restrictions were prolonged up to 24th of December. UPDATE: Restrictions were prolonged up to 24th of December.
institution_status: This type of business  ("Other Businesses") is closed/locked down
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Ministry/Department of Justice,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government

description: From 7 November 2020, entering the costumer areas of business premises of any sort (or outdoor markets), sports grounds and the visitor areas of leisure facilities is allowed if certain conditions are met (see [type_business_var]). For business premises, sports grounds and leisure facilities, conditions have changed when compared to the regulatory situation of October 25. The policy is slated to end on December 31. UPDATE: From 3 November to 30 November 2020, previous provisions are replaced by temporary and specific protection measures against the spread of COVID-19. For business premises, these are the same as has been enacted on May 1, with the addition that face mask have to be "close-fitting". For sports grounds, there are the same as has been enacted on  May 1, yet, slightly narrowed and relaxed and with the addition of COVID-19 prevention concept provisions. For leisure facilities, these are the same as has been enacted on May 1, yet, slightly narrowed and relaxed in general. These changes are slated to be replaced by the previous set of policies on December 1.
institution_status: This type of business  ("Retail Businesses") is allowed to open with conditions
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Fines

description:
In Austria, A new government plan to mandate restaurants and bars to collect the names, addresses and contact information of all their guests has drawn the ire of the gastronomy sector. Announced on August 27. 

This ended after new lockdown was implemented and gastronomy had to close UPDATE: This ended after new lockdown was implemented
institution_status: This type of business ("Restaurants") is allowed to open with no conditions attached
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
From May 29th, hotels and other accomodation facilities can reopen in Austria. Nevertheless, certain control measures have to be insured: 
- Ensure a minimum distance of 1 meter (Place information by means of displays, signs, stands, floor markings or other aids in the entrance areas and at the reception of the accommodation company and etc).
- Design the catering area (Observe guidelines for catering establishments for general information)
- Adapt additional offers (fitness areas and wellness areas, according to their requirements)
- Place recommendations for behavior that are clearly visible to the guest.

From 3rd of November, this policy is no longer valid (hotels must close) UPDATE: From 3rd of November, this policy is no longer valid
institution_status: This type of business  ("Other Businesses") is allowed to open with conditions
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: In Austria, the original policy limited the working time and number of people of restaurants and bars, as well as mandatory masks wearing requirements for customers and personnel existed (from May 15th). Starting on June 15th, people will be able to sit on a restaurant table with more than 4 people (also from different households), masks will be mandatory only for personnel and restaurants and bars can stay opened until 1:00 am in the morning (before until 23:00). UPDATE: Due to a nationwide lockdown on November 3rd, all cafes, bars and restaurants need to close. Only take-away service is allowed.
institution_status: This type of business  ("Restaurants") is allowed to open with conditions
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: From 7 November 2020, the Federal Ministry for Social Affairs, Health, Care and Consumer Protection in Austria enacts that entering the premises of all modes of operation in the catering industry is allowed if certain conditions are met (see [type_business_var]). Conditions have changed when compared to the regulatory situation of November 1. For some facilities, following these rules is not explicitly mandatory (see exceptions section). The policy is slated to end on November 22.
institution_status: This type of business  ("Restaurants") is allowed to open with conditions
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: From 3 November 2020, entering the costumer areas of business premises of any sort (or outdoor markets) is allowed if social distancing, face covering or other infection protection measures are followed (see [type_business_var]). Entering sports grounds for carrying out sports activities is, with exceptions (which are almost the same as has been enacted on May 1, yet, slightly narrowed and relaxed and with the addition of COVID-19 prevention concept provisions), prohibited. Entering leisure facilities for entertaining, amusing or recreational purposes is, with exceptions (which are almost the same as has been enacted on May 1, yet, slightly narrowed and relaxed in general), prohibited. The policy is slated to end on November 30 and replaced by the previous set of policies on December 1. UPDATE: From 11 November 2020, trade facilities selling goods are, with few exceptions, required to have opening hours that go from no earlier than the time that has been in place in the last 4 weeks based on the workday that is next to the present policy changes, to 7 pm at the longest.
institution_status: This type of business  ("Retail Businesses") is allowed to open with conditions
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Fines,Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: From 11 November 2020, entering the costumer areas of business premises of any sort (or outdoor markets) is allowed if social distancing, face covering or other infection protection measures are followed (see [type_business_var]). Entering sports grounds for carrying out sports activities is, with exceptions, prohibited. Entering leisure facilities for entertaining, amusing or recreational purposes is, with exceptions, prohibited. For business premises, conditions have changed when compared to the regulatory situation of November 3. The policy is slated to end on November 30 and replaced by the previous set of policies on December 1. UPDATE: From 17 November 2020, entering (and driving along) the costumer areas of trade facilities for purchasing goods, service providers for utilizing physical services and leisure facilities for utilizing leisure facility services is, with exceptions, prohibited. Entering the costumer areas of business premises (or outdoor markets) is attached to certain conditions. If possible, services ought to be provided electronically. Exceptions to sports ground restrictions are narrowed when compared to the regulatory situation before. For when athletes are tested SARS-CoV-2-positive, restrictions that follow are relaxed when compared to the regulatory situation before.
institution_status: This type of business  ("Retail Businesses") is allowed to open with conditions

description: From 17 November 2020, entering the costumer areas of defined trade or leisure facilities or in the context of defined service provisions is, with exceptions, prohibited. Besides that, entering the costumer areas of business premises of any sort (or outdoor markets) is allowed if certain conditions are met. Entering sports grounds for carrying out sports activities is, with exceptions (which are narrowed when compared to the regulatory situation of November 11), prohibited. The policy is slated to end on December 6. UPDATE: From 27 November 2020, exceptions for bilateral business-related stores (dealings?) ("Geschäfte") now also apply to service providers (for utilizing physical services). Exceptions for the selling of safety and emergency products are differentiated. Conditions for entering the costumer areas of business premises are differentiated with respect to services for education and training purposes. In the context of sports grounds, airports are now, in addition to airfields, also considered sports grounds.
institution_status: This type of business  ("Retail Businesses") is closed/locked down
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Fines,Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: In Austria, from 7th of December, retail shops (and services, like friseur) can reopen again. The trade will open again from December 7th, the shops may stay open until 7 p.m. at the latest. It is mandatory to wear mouth and nose protection. For customer areas there is a limit of 10 m 2 per customer.

description: From 17 November 2020, entering the costumer areas of defined trade or leisure facilities or in the context of defined service provisions is, with exceptions, prohibited. Besides that, entering the costumer areas of business premises of any sort (or outdoor markets) is allowed if certain conditions are met. Entering sports grounds for carrying out sports activities is, with exceptions (which are narrowed when compared to the regulatory situation of November 11), prohibited. The policy is slated to end on December 6. UPDATE: From 7 December 2020, for business premises, provisions as had been enacted on November 3 are reintroduced with the addition that for shopping centres, provisions related to the space of costumer areas are differentiated, entering connective structures is regulated, consumption of meals and drinks is prohibited, a COVID-19 prevention concept is to be worked out and implemented, exceptions to social distancing measures in the context of services where minimum distance provisions cannot be followed are attached to the condition that in the meantime no meals or drinks are consumed and trade facilities selling goods have, with exceptions, to close at 7 pm at the least. For sports grounds, provisions are the same as had been enacted on November 3, with the exception that restrictions imposed upon athletes following a SARS-CoV-2-positive test are relaxed when compared to before and airfields are no longer explicitly mentioned. For leisure facilities, provisions are the same as had been enacted on November 3, yet, slightly differentiated.
institution_status: This type of business  ("Retail Businesses") is closed/locked down
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Fines,Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: From 17 November 2020, entering the costumer areas of defined trade or leisure facilities or in the context of defined service provisions is, with exceptions, prohibited. Besides that, entering the costumer areas of business premises of any sort (or outdoor markets) is allowed if certain conditions are met. Entering sports grounds for carrying out sports activities is, with exceptions (which are narrowed when compared to the regulatory situation of November 11), prohibited. The policy is slated to end on December 6. UPDATE: From 7 December 2020, for business premises, provisions as had been enacted on November 3 are reintroduced with the addition that for shopping centres, provisions related to the space of costumer areas are differentiated, entering connective structures is regulated, consumption of meals and drinks is prohibited, a COVID-19 prevention concept is to be worked out and implemented, exceptions to social distancing measures in the context of services where minimum distance provisions cannot be followed are attached to the condition that in the meantime no meals or drinks are consumed and trade facilities selling goods have, with exceptions, to close at 7 pm at the least. For sports grounds, provisions are the same as had been enacted on November 3, with the exception that restrictions imposed upon athletes following a SARS-CoV-2-positive test are relaxed when compared to before and airfields are no longer explicitly mentioned. For leisure facilities, provisions are the same as had been enacted on November 3, yet, slightly differentiated.

description:
Original policy: Health Minister Rudolf Anschober (Greens) presented a preview of the planned “Corona-Ampel,” the coronavirus “traffic-light” warning systems for Austrian regions that should be tested in August and fully launched in September.

Update: In Austria, CoV-Ampel (corona traffic light system) was officially launched on September 4. restrictions will be valid starting from September 11.
The system consists of four colors, from green (low risk) to red (very high risk).
When the traffic light is yellow:
-Masks must be worn inside stores, restaurants, schools, and at events.
-Events with reserved seating arrangements will be limited to 2,500 people.
-Events without reserved seats will be limited to 100 people.
-To host events with 500 or more people, one must first submit a request at the respective district office.
-Outdoor events with reserved seats are limited to 5000 people. Without reserved seats, outdoor events are limited to 100 attendees. When seated, guests are not required to wear a mask.
-When the light is green, hygiene guidelines will still be enforced.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Ministry/Department of Justice,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government,Police

description:
With election day approaching fast in Vienna, safety measures are being put in place for voting in the Vienna election on October 11, 2020.
Voters can visit one of 1,494 voting stations between 7:00 and 15:00 on October 11.
Facemasks must be worn inside the voting stations and voters are requested to bring their own pen with them to fill out the ballot.
Postal ballots (also called absentee ballots, Wahlkarte) can already be mailed in or submitted. Voters who have not received one in the mail can also pick it up at the Magistrate for your district.
type_sub_cat: Annually recurring event allowed to occur with certain conditions
target_geog_level: One or more cities within a country

description:
Since March, Austrian national policy set restrictions and has forbidden visits senior houses, from May 4 this policy is no longer valid (visits from May 4 are available, but under strict conditions to protect the people living there).

Some of the restricions:
-Coordination of visits by the facility, an appointment in advance is required.
-Set limited hours of visit by the facility.
-Limitation of the number of visitors.
-In the first step, the visits to the facilities should only take place individually (one visitor per resident). 
 UPDATE: Since March national policy set restrictions and has forbidden visits senior houses, from May 4 this policy is no longer valid (visits from May 4 are available, but under strict conditions to protect the people living there).

Some of the restricions:
-Coordination of visits by the facility, an appointment in advance is required.
-Set limited hours of visit by the facility.
-Limitation of the number of visitors.
-In the first step, the visits to the facilities should only take place individually (one visitor per resident).
In Carinthia from March 13, ban on visiting hospitals UPDATE: The policy ended on May 4th 2020.
